Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Interfacial Flows Driven by Antisymmetric Stresses in Ferrofluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 151113
PI: Rinaldi, Carlos

Ferrofluids are fluids that respond to magnetic fields. This project examines the fluid dynamics of a ferrofluid composed of magnetic particles in a suspending liquid. The project focuses on the motion of the fluid near a fluid-air interface where interesting connections have been observed experimentally between flow near the interface and flow in the bulk fluid. The velocity of the ferrofluid near various kinds of interfaces will be measured in well-defined flows. The results will be used to test the validity of theory that describes the appropriate dynamical conditions at the interface. The project will provide research training to graduate and undergraduate students and will develop Web-based educational videos that explore the fluid dynamics of ferrofluids.

The objective of the project is to validate experimentally appropriate interfacial boundary conditions on linear and internal angular momentum at ferrofluid-air, ferrofluid-non-ferrofluid, and ferrofluid-ferrofluid interfaces. Velocity profiles near the interfaces and in the bulk fluids will be measured for various prototype flows, and results will be used to develop models that can be extended to more complicated geometries, including ferrofluid droplets. The results should help clarify the appropriate interfacial conditions to use for fluid systems that exhibit antisymmetric stresses, which, in turn, can be incorporated into engineering design of various applications involving ferrofluids with interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made fundamental and transformative contributions to the field of ferrohydrodynamics, the study of suspensions of magnetic nanoparticles, also known as ferrofluids. A combination of experimental and simulation work enhanced our understanding of the response of magnetic nanoparticles and ferrofluids in time varying magnetic fields and the interfacial momentum balance at ferrofluid interfaces. Studies conducted under this project provided insight into the effects of particle-particle magnetic interactions on capture/assembly in magnetic field gradients and response to oscillating and time-varying magnetic fields. This understanding will support development of novel applications of ferrofluids in cancer therapy and biomedical imaging. New simulation algorithms were developed to model the internal dipole orientation behavior of magnetic nanoparticles in time-varying magnetic fields. These algorithms provided fundamental understanding on the role of internal dipole reorientation on particle response to time-varying magnetic fields. Prior models of ferrofluid flow in rotating and oscillating magnetic fields, with and without ferrofluid-air interfaces, were extended to conditions of non-small magnetic fields. Experimental measurements evaluated the roles of body couple and interfacial stresses on the flow of ferrofluids in rotating magnetic fields. The activities undertaken through this project motivated and trained new generations of scientists and engineers, including students from under-represented groups. This project supported one doctoral student and three undergraduates through Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU). The doctoral student obtained his Ph.D. degree and will soon start a postdoctoral fellow position at the University of Delaware Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering. One of the undergraduates is a veteran of the armed forces who was a community college student at the time and after the REU experience was admitted to the Mechanical Engineering program at the University of Florida. The other two undergraduates are currently pursuing doctoral studies in Chemical Engineering. One of the undergraduate students supported is a female Puerto Rican.
